definitions.labels: North American EnglishBritish EnglishBritish EnglishNorth American English

examples.text: I'm going to have to find a new apartment pretty soon.
We were pretty disappointed with the quality of the food.
It came at the end of a pretty miserable week.
Flying those planes was pretty hard work.

definitions.definition: to be in a good situation, especially when others are not

examples.text: With profits at record levels, the company’s certainly sitting pretty this year.
One dog looks pretty much like another to me.
He goes out pretty well every night.
The first stage is pretty near finished.

wordOrigin: Old English prættig; related to Middle Dutch pertich ‘brisk, clever’, obsolete Dutch prettig ‘humorous, sporty’, from a West Germanic base meaning ‘trick’. The sense development ‘deceitful, cunning, clever, skilful, admirable, pleasing, nice’ has parallels in adjectives such as canny, fine, nice, etc.
